results.title: Quilts of Understanding
results.creator_credit: Jenene Egan and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
In this story, Jenene tells of her life-long passion for all things craft. Recounting one of her proudest moments, she speaks about some patches that she created for a collaborative quilt-making project, which was exhibited at her Uniting Church and throughout regional Victoria.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Radiation
results.creator_credit: Hugh O'Connor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From a sun-drenched bathing beach to an awesome “gamma garden,” this film explores how heat, radio waves, x-rays and gamma rays affect various forms of life. It takes you to the radiological department of a modern hospital, to Canada’s atomic research center at Chalk River, and to the Brookhaven National Laboratory in the United States, where plant growth is subjected to gamma radiation.

results.title: The Next Chapter
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Craig Dawson
results.brief_description:
Craig Dawson shares his personal experience of being diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis, a disease that his grandmother also suffered from. Craig dedicates this story to her.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Racial stereotyping
results.creator_credit: Geoff Cawthorn, Margaret Pomeranz, Ian Phipps, AFTRS and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: This program, from the ‘Reel to Real’ series investigates why cinema and TV are so Anglo-Celtic, and aimed at middle America and suburban Australia. Top Australian critics discuss cinema in its wider context and cover topics such as: does being politically sound guarantee non-stereotypical filmmaking? How did the immigrant character break out of the gangster stereotype? How did black actors break out of servant roles or the musical exception. Spike Lee may be black, but what is he doing for women? Should he be applauded or marauded? This documentary will stimulate deep thinking about film, modern culture and society, and how they in turn, effect each other.

results.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence
results.creator_credit: Christine Olsen, Phil Noyce, Jabel Films, South Australian Film Corporation, Premium Movie Partnership and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ is based on the true story of three Aboriginal girls, Molly, Daisy and Gracie, who in 1931 were forcibly removed from their mothers and home in Jigalong, Western Australia, and sent to a settlement 2000 kilometres away to be trained as domestic servants and inducted into White culture. Upon arrival, the girls are instantly averse to their strange, rather grotesque new world, and decide to take matters into their own hands by attempting an escape and return home. Here begins the girls’ seemingly eternal, epic journey across the harsh Australian desert landscape, with all odds against them except for a rabbit-proof fence as their guide home. In a moving finale, they are reunited with their mothers and, significantly, their culture. Though it is a specifically Australian story (the Stolen Generations and the White Australia Policy), director Phillip Noyce tells it in such a way that emphasises universal qualities of tragedy and heroism. He opts for an even-handed portrayal of the past, steering clear of images of oppression or subjugation and any chastising of White Culture, and instead emphasises optimism and survival. The film is adapted from a book of the same title by author, Doris Pilkington, daughter of the real-life Molly and ‘Stolen Generation’ victim. Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.

results.title: Quills
results.creator_credit: Philip Kaufman, Nick Wechsler, Peter Kaufman, Julia Chasma, Walrus and Associates, Industry Entertainment, Hollywood Partners and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: Paris, 1804 - following the bloody climate of the French Revolution erotic writer, the Marquis de Sade, resides in the Charenton Asylum for the insane where he continues to pen his sadomasochistic literature. When his latest tome upsets Napoleon, Dr Royer-Collard (Michael Caine) is despatched to ensure that de Sade be published no more. In charge of the asylum is a benevolent priest Coulmier (Joaquin Phoenix) who allows de Sade’s writings as a form of therapy. Coulmier and Royer-Collard soon come into conflict about the treatment of the Marquis and the running of the asylum. But the priest faces a greater challenge - his lust for a common laundress sparks suppressed desires, but it is she who is sneaking out the Marquis’ incendiary prose. Meanwhile the doctor marries a virginal bride, brought up in a nunnery, who he mercilessly abuses. Philip Kaufman (The Unbearable lightness of being, Henry and June, The Right stuff) presents the Marquis de Sade as a mostly harmless presence (ignoring his historical squalidity) - compared to the enshrined corruption within the Church. Kaufman ably captures the fetid environs of the asylum; the barely contained carnal desires of the inmates, their depravity and insanity, inflaming the nightmarish atmosphere of these scenes. Rush puts in an impressive, if manic, performance as a tormented artist, whose prose may inspire acts of passion and murder witnessed throughout the film.

results.title: Peter & Paul and the Christian revolution
results.creator_credit: Margaret Koval, Patricia Aste and Koval Films LLC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Traces the life of early Christians Peter and Paul, who faced powerful obstacles - including the mighty Roman Empire, political persecution and crippling personal disagreements - in their attempts to spread the word of Jesus. Episode 1. “The Rock and the river” - With the Messiah dead and their cause deemed subversive, the followers of Jesus face a bleak future, until their hope is re-invigorated by a vision of the risen Jesus. A former persecutor of Christians, Peter soon becomes an indomitable figure, uniting the group into a tight community of ardent believers. Paul, educated, passionate, determined and dogmatic, uses his formidable talents to spread his new beliefs around the Roman Empire. Episode 2. “The Empire and the Kingdom” - Led by missionaries, Christian ideas continue to spread among Jews and non-Jews throughout the Empire; hostile locals, imperial forces and conflicting ideas threaten the future of the movement. Paul splits with his former allies, establishing churches in his image; in 70 AD, after decades of tensions, a four-year war erupts that destroys much of Jerusalem, but the communities established by Paul survive and grow. Fascinating work features the words of Paul and other ancient writers, historical re-enactments and interviews with contemporary scholars.

results.title: Quintet
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Robert Altman’s “Quintet” was received with almost universal derision when it was released in 1979. He had made his reputation with very contemporary, very insisive and very American films. “Quintet” is strikingly different: heavily symbolic, with a mannerist visual palette, it was a departure for Altman and sees him explore themes associated with European existentialism. In a desolate future Ice-Age the remaining inhabitants of Earth are facing their extinction. Paul Newman plays a hunter, returning to his birthplace, accompanied by a pregnant woman (a startling occurrence in a world where most people are no longer able to reproduce). Her murder leads him to a confrontation with the players of Quintet, an elaborate and violent game which is the main activity of the future. As he becomes more involved in the strategies and rules of Quintet, he finds himself losing his identity. This complex and philosophical science-fiction film, creates a future as it may have been envisaged by Kafka and is a uniquely original meditation on the struggle and meaning of human “free will”. Undeniably difficult and ambitious, the film deserves a more serious critical engagement than that offered by contemporary English-language critics. Also stars Vittorio Gassman, Bibi Anderson and Fernando Rey.
